questions.text: A patient suffered a blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago. He now complains of blurred vision. On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iridodialysis

 

Explanation:


 Iridodialysis is a specific type of traumatic eye injury characterized by:

 

  • Separation of the iris from its root (ciliary body attachment)
  • Typically caused by blunt trauma
  • Results in a D-shaped pupil
  • Occurs due to direct mechanical force disrupting the iris attachment

 

Other potential traumatic eye findings include:

 

  • Sphincter tear
  • Hyphema (blood in anterior chamber)
  • Traumatic cataract
  • Vossius ring (iron deposition on anterior lens capsule)

 

 

  • Retinal or zonular dialysis

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Vossius ring: Incorrect. While a Vossius ring is a traumatic finding (pigment deposition on anterior lens capsule), it does not explain the D-shaped pupil or significant structural change described in the question.

 

 

Option C. Cycloiriditis: Incorrect. This refers to inflammation of the ciliary body and iris, which is not specifically associated with blunt trauma or a D-shaped pupil.

 

Option D. Ankyloblepharon: Incorrect. This is an adhesion of the upper and lower eyelids, which is not related to the described traumatic finding or D-shaped pupil.



 

Educational Objective:


Iridodialysis is a specific traumatic eye injury characterized by separation of the iris from its root, typically resulting from blunt force trauma and presenting with a distinctive D-shaped pupil.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient having a ↓ MCV, ↓ MCH, ↓ transferrin saturation, ↓ serum ferritin, and ↑ Total iron binding capacity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron deficiency anemia

 

The lab findings indicate a microcytic hypochromic anemia, as shown by decreased Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).

 

The iron profile further confirms iron deficiency anemia: low transferrin saturation, low serum ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), and increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), which reflects the body’s attempt to bind more iron due to deficiency.

 

These findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia, where the primary pathology is a lack of iron needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalassemia: Thalassemia also presents as microcytic hypochromic anemia, but typically shows normal or increased serum ferritin and normal TIBC due to intact iron stores. The pattern of iron studies here does not fit thalassemia.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This condition often shows low serum iron, but it is characterized by normal or increased ferritin and decreased TIBC, opposite to the findings in this question.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis and abnormal iron incorporation into hemoglobin, leading to ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow. Serum iron is usually increased, and TIBC is normal or decreased, which does not match the iron deficiency profile described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is identified by microcytic hypochromic anemia with low serum ferritin, low transferrin saturation, and high TIBC, reflecting the body’s response to insufficient iron availability for hemoglobin synthesis.

choices.text: Medical colleges and hospitals are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level
Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level
CHC is primary level, Subcentre and PHC are secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level
CHC is primary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level

questions.text: The image regarding health care system levels in the country. Correct arrangement about the levels of health care is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level

 

The healthcare system in India is organized into three levels:

 

  • Primary Level: First level of contact between population and health system, comprising of sub-centers and primary health centers (PHCs)
  • Secondary Level: First referral level, specialized care provided through community health centers (CHCs)
  • Tertiary Level: Second referral level, highly specialized care provided through medical colleges and their attached hospitals

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Medical colleges and hospitals are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level: Incorrect. This completely reverses the actual arrangement. Medical colleges provide tertiary care, not primary care.

 

Option C. CHC is primary level, Subcentre and PHC are secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level: Incorrect. CHC cannot be primary level as it provides specialized care and serves as first referral unit. Sub-centers and PHCs are primary care facilities, not secondary.

 

Option D. CHC is primary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level: Incorrect. This arrangement is completely wrong. CHC provides secondary care, medical colleges provide tertiary care, and sub-centers/PHCs provide primary care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The three-tier healthcare delivery system in India consists of:

 

  • Primary level: Sub-centers and PHCs (First contact point)
  • Secondary level: CHCs (First referral level)
  • Tertiary level: Medical colleges and hospitals (Second referral level)

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Semicircular canal

 

The human balance system, or vestibular system, relies on structures within the inner ear to maintain balance and equilibrium. The primary structures involved in balance are the semicircular canals and the vestibule (which contains the utricle and saccule).

 

Semicircular canal: There are three semicircular canals (anterior, posterior, and lateral) in each ear, and they detect rotational movements of the head. The semicircular canals contain the crista ampullaris within the ampullae, which respond to angular movements, making them directly responsible for maintaining balance during such movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organ of Corti: This is the sensory organ of hearing located within the cochlea. It is responsible for detecting sound and converting it into nerve impulses but does not play a role in balance.

 

Option B. Cochlea: This spiral-shaped organ is part of the inner ear and is also involved in hearing. It converts sound vibrations into electrical signals that are sent to the brain but is not involved in balance.

 

Option C. Vestibule: This part of the inner ear contains the utricle and saccule, which are essential for detecting linear movements and head position relative to gravity. While the vestibule is crucial for balance, the specific detection of angular movements is primarily attributed to the semicircular canals.

 

While both the utricle and saccule, and the semicircular canals, are important for balance, the semicircular canals are particularly crucial for detecting angular motion, which is vital for maintaining equilibrium during movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The semicircular canals are critical for detecting angular movements and maintaining balance and equilibrium in conjunction with the vestibule, which detects linear movements and head position relative to gravity.

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not lie in close contact with the humerus? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Musculocutaneous Nerve

 

The musculocutaneous nerve does not lie in close contact with the humerus along its course. This nerve originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C7) and travels through the anterior compartment of the arm. Importantly, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and then passes between the biceps and brachialis muscles, staying within the soft tissue compartments without establishing a close relationship with the humeral bone.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis) and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm for sensory distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary Nerve - This nerve does lie in close contact with the humerus, specifically at the surgical neck. It courses around the neck of the humerus in the quadrangular space, making it vulnerable to injury in proximal humeral fractures and anterior shoulder dislocations.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve - This nerve has an intimate relationship with the humerus as it travels in the spiral groove (radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it the most commonly injured nerve in humeral shaft fractures, especially in the middle and lower third.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve - The ulnar nerve comes into close contact w`ith the humerus at the medial epicondyle. At the elbow, it passes behind the medial epicondyle in the cubital tunnel, making it vulnerable to injury at this site (cubital tunnel syndrome).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nerves that lie in close contact with bones are more susceptible to injury during fractures, and the musculocutaneous nerve is relatively protected as it travels through soft tissue compartments without establishing close contact with the humerus, unlike the axillary, radial, and ulnar nerves.

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Opium

 

Explanation:

 

  • In 18th & 19th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. 
  • By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Option D. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:
