questions.text: What is the most prevalent defect observed in Congenital Rubella Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Deafness

 

Explanation:

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is characterized by a triad of defects including sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities (such as cataracts), and congenital heart defects. Among these manifestations, sensorineural deafness is the most common and prevalent defect, affecting approximately 80% of infants with CRS. The hearing impairment is typically bilateral and can range from mild to profound.

 

The classic triad of CRS includes:

  • Sensorineural deafness (most common)
  • Eye abnormalities (cataracts, microphthalmia, glaucoma)
  • Cardiac defects (most commonly PDA)

 

The risk of defects is highest when maternal infection occurs during the first trimester, particularly before 11 weeks of gestation, when the risk of defects is approximately 90%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract - Incorrect. While cataracts are a characteristic feature of CRS, they are less common than hearing impairment, occurring in approximately 30-40% of affected infants.

 

Option C. Heart defect - Incorrect. Cardiac defects (particularly PDA, followed by peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis) occur in about 50-60% of CRS cases, making them less prevalent than deafness.

 

Option D. Microcephaly - Incorrect. Microcephaly is observed in CRS but at a lower frequency compared to hearing impairment. It is part of the neurological manifestations that may include developmental delay and intellectual disability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural deafness is the most common manifestation of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, which is why hearing assessment is critical for all infants with suspected in-utero rubella exposure, even in the absence of other clinical features.

questions.text: A young patient presents in a multi-specialty hospital with sudden onset chest pain since 1 hour with ECG showing ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary Angioplasty

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms and ECG findings indicative of an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The presence of ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF confirms the diagnosis. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as primary angioplasty, is the best treatment for STEMI if it can be performed promptly. PCI is preferred because it directly opens the blocked coronary artery, restoring blood flow more quickly and effectively than thrombolytic therapy.

 

Note - If Primary PCI not possible or delayed due to some reasons then thrombolytic therapy (dual antiplatelet therapy) is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots but is considered when PCI is not available or will be delayed.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Another thrombolytic agent, similar to alteplase, used when PCI is not an option.

 

Option D. Dual Antiplatelet therapy: This is an essential part of the initial management of STEMI, involving a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (like clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel). However, it is not the definitive treatment compared to PCI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary angioplasty (PCI) is the best treatment for patients presenting with STEMI, especially when it can be performed within the recommended time frame, as it effectively restores blood flow to the affected myocardium. ​

questions.text: Lymph from a cancerous breast primarily drains into which of the following nodes? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Anterior (pectoral) nodes

 

Explanation: 

 

The lymphatic drainage of the breast primarily flows into the anterior (pectoral) group of axillary lymph nodes. These nodes are positioned along the lateral thoracic vessels at the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle. Approximately 75% of the lymph from the breast tissue drains into the axillary nodes, with the anterior group receiving the major portion. This makes the anterior (pectoral) nodes the first-line lymph nodes to receive drainage from cancerous breast tissue, particularly from the upper lateral quadrant where breast cancer most commonly occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Apical nodes: Located at the apex of the axilla, these nodes receive lymph secondarily after it has passed through other axillary node groups. They're not the primary recipients of breast lymph drainage.
  • Option C. Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes: These nodes receive about 20% of breast lymphatic drainage, primarily from the medial quadrants of the breast, but are not the main drainage pathway.
  • Option D. Supraclavicular nodes: These become involved primarily in advanced cases of breast cancer. They receive lymph only after it has passed through multiple other node groups.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anterior (pectoral) lymph nodes are the primary recipients of lymphatic drainage from the breast, making them crucial for early detection and staging of breast malignancy.

questions.text: The primary action of Inhibin is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Inhibits FSH secretion

 

Explanation:

 

Inhibin functions as a hormone that specifically inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary. This is part of the negative feedback mechanism in the reproductive system where inhibin is produced by the gonads (ovaries in females, testes in males) and acts directly on the pituitary to suppress FSH release while having minimal effect on LH secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Inhibits LH secretion - Inhibin does not have a significant direct inhibitory effect on LH secretion. LH secretion is primarily regulated by GnRH from the hypothalamus and feedback from sex steroids.
  • Option C. Inhibits prolactin secretion - Prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine (prolactin-inhibiting hormone) from the hypothalamus, not by inhibin. The factors regulating prolactin secretion include dopamine, TRH, estrogens, and various physiological states like stress and suckling.
  • Option D. Inhibits estradiol synthesis - Inhibin doesn't directly inhibit estradiol synthesis. Estradiol synthesis is primarily regulated by FSH and LH acting on the ovaries. Inhibin works at the pituitary level to regulate FSH, not at the ovarian level to regulate estradiol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin serves as a negative feedback regulator specifically targeting FSH secretion, allowing precise control of the reproductive cycle through selective modulation of gonadotropin levels.

questions.text: The type of cataract associated with blunt trauma is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

Rosette cataract is a type of cataract typically associated with blunt trauma to the eye. This type of cataract has a characteristic flower-like appearance, resembling the petals of a rose, hence the name "rosette." Blunt trauma can cause disruption in the lens fibers, leading to the formation of this unique pattern, which can be located either in the anterior or posterior cortex of the lens.

 

 

Vossius ring:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower cataract: Sunflower cataract is seen in patients with Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism. It is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Option B. Snowflake cataract: Snowflake cataract is typically seen in diabetic patients and is characterized by the presence of multiple small, white opacities in the lens. It is not related to blunt trauma.

 

 

Option D. Christmas tree cataract: Christmas tree cataract is seen in patients with myotonic dystrophy. It presents with brightly colored, polychromatic crystals within the lens, which resemble the decorations on a Christmas tree. This type of cataract is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is the type of cataract that develops following blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by its distinctive flower-like pattern.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided defect in both eyes with central sparing. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Explanation: 


The patient presents with a right-sided visual field defect in both eyes with central (macular) sparing. This pattern is characteristic of a homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is caused by a lesion in the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory affecting the occipital cortex.

 

Homonymous means "same-sided," referring to the fact that the same side of the visual field is affected in both eyes (in this case, the right side). The term hemianopia indicates that approximately half of the visual field is lost. The macular sparing (preservation of central vision) occurs because the macular representation in the occipital cortex often has dual blood supply from both the posterior and middle cerebral arteries, making it less vulnerable to a single vascular insult.

 

This visual field defect is typically caused by a left occipital lobe lesion, as visual pathways cross at the optic chiasm, resulting in contralateral field defects. The most common cause is a posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion or embolism affecting the occipital lobe.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic tract lesion: Incorrect. Optic tract lesions also produce homonymous hemianopia, but they typically do not spare the macula. Additionally, optic tract lesions often cause incongruous defects (slightly different patterns in each eye) and may be associated with relative afferent pupillary defect. The defects from optic tract lesions tend to be less symmetric between the two eyes compared to occipital cortex lesions.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma lesion: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia (loss of the temporal visual fields in both eyes) due to compression of the crossing nasal retinal fibers. This pattern is described as a heteronymous hemianopia, not a homonymous one. Common causes include pituitary adenomas, craniopharyngiomas, or meningiomas. Chiasmal lesions do not produce the right-sided defect in both eyes.

 

Option D. Heteronymous hemianopia with central sparing: Incorrect. Heteronymous hemianopia refers to visual field defects on opposite sides in the two eyes (e.g., right temporal and left nasal, which is bitemporal hemianopia; or right nasal and left temporal, which is binasal hemianopia). This pattern is typically seen with lesions affecting the optic chiasm or the immediate pre- or post-chiasmal pathways. 

 

Educational Objective: 


Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is characterized by loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes with preservation of central vision, typically resulting from an occipital lobe lesion in the territory of the posterior cerebral artery (contralateral to the field defect).

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid
Hemolytic anemia is a feature
B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

 

Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytes) in the bone marrow and blood due to impaired DNA synthesis. Folate is crucial for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, the building blocks of DNA, which is why DNA synthesis is directly affected.

 

  • High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels increase because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal, which helps differentiate folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, where methylmalonic acid levels are elevated.
  • B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is recommended because both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies can lead to similar hematologic manifestations, like megaloblastic anemia. However, treating a patient with folic acid alone when they have an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency can mask the hematologic symptoms while allowing neurological damage to progress. Therefore, it is safer to supplement both B12 and folate unless B12 deficiency has been ruled out.
  • Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: Folate is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, which are necessary for DNA replication. Specifically, folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units during the synthesis of these nucleotides. In its absence, DNA synthesis is impaired, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: This statement is true and correctly describes the biochemical changes in folate deficiency.

 

Option C. B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is a true statement and an important clinical practice to avoid masking B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: This statement is true because folate is directly involved in nucleotide synthesis, which is critical for DNA replication and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with infertility, and he has chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener's syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kartagener's syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.

 

Infertility in males is also a common feature due to the dysfunction of cilia and flagella, leading to impaired sperm motility.

 

Situs inversus is a condition where the major visceral organs are mirrored from their normal positions, often seen in Kartagener's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: While patients with cystic fibrosis may also present with sinusitis, infertility, and bronchiectasis, they do not typically have situs inversus, which is specific to Kartagener's syndrome.

 

Option C. Mucoviscidosis: This is another term for cystic fibrosis, and thus the same reasoning applies as above.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: This genetic disorder can present with infertility but does not include chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, or situs inversus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, and is associated with infertility in males due to primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation

 

Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and ACE inhibitors are known to be absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. They can cause fetal toxicity, particularly in the second and third trimesters, leading to complications such as renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and even fetal death. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Paracetamol: Generally considered safe for use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Cefixime: A cephalosporin antibiotic, also considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: An antibiotic that is commonly used and considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as captopril, are absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal toxicity and complications.

questions.text: What is the recommended target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) for neonates at 5 minutes after birth according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 2010 guidelines? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 80-85%

 

Explanation: 

 

According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, the target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in neonates at 5 minutes after birth is 80-85%. This is part of the gradual progression of normal oxygen saturation values in the first 10 minutes after birth. The preductal SpO₂ is measured in the right upper limb (right hand).

 

The normal SpO₂ progression after birth is:

 

  • At 1 minute: 60-65%
  • At 2 minutes: 65-70%
  • At 3 minutes: 70-75%
  • At 4 minutes: 75-80%
  • At 5 minutes: 80-85%
  • At 10 minutes: 85-95%

 

To remember-

 

  • Start from 60
  • THEN ADD 5 for every minute till 5 minutes, only for the last 10 minutes - add 10
  • These targets acknowledge the normal physiological transition from fetal to neonatal circulation, where saturation gradually increases as the lungs expand and the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70-75% - This is the target SpO₂ at 3 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option B. 75-80% - This is the target SpO₂ at 4 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option D. 85-95% - This is the target SpO₂ at 10 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal physiologic transition after birth involves a gradual increase in oxygen saturation, with a target SpO₂ of 80-85% at 5 minutes of life. These targeted ranges guide oxygen therapy during neonatal resuscitation to avoid both hypoxemia and hyperoxemia.

questions.text: The posterior superior iliac spine is at the level of?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. S2

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is an important bony landmark located at the posterior end of the iliac crest. The PSIS lies in the floor of a dimple about 5 cm lateral to the median plane and at the level of the second sacral spine (S2). This dimple is visible on the surface of the body and corresponds to the middle of the sacroiliac joint. The PSIS serves as an important landmark for various clinical examinations and procedures related to the lower back and pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. L5 - The highest point of the iliac crest corresponds to the interval between the spines of L3 and L4 vertebrae, not the PSIS. L5 is lower than this level but still above the level of PSIS.
  • Option B. S1 - The S1 vertebral level is above the level of the PSIS. The S1 foramen is an important landmark for nerve root identification, but it doesn't align with the PSIS.
  • Option D. S3 - The S3 vertebral level is below the level of the PSIS. The PSIS specifically aligns with the S2 vertebral level, not S3.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is located at the level of the second sacral spine (S2) and serves as a clinically important surface landmark for identifying the sacroiliac joint and related structures.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue? ( NEET PG  2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Specifically, these taste fibers travel via the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve. The chorda tympani leaves the facial nerve in the facial canal, traverses the middle ear cavity, and joins the lingual nerve (a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve). Through this pathway, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue reaches the nucleus of the tractus solitarius in the brainstem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a. Glossopharyngeal nerve - This nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and the vallate papillae, not the anterior two-thirds.

 

Option c. Vagus nerve - This nerve provides taste sensation from the epiglottis and a small area of the pharynx, not from the anterior tongue.

 

Option d. Hypoglossal nerve - This is primarily a motor nerve that supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It does not carry taste sensation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the facial nerve via its chorda tympani branch, which joins the lingual nerve to reach its destination.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?  NEET PG 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Candidal intertrigo

 

The condition shown in the image is Candidal intertrigo.

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  1. Candidal intertrigo:
    • Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches of opposing skin surfaces, with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold.
    • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.
    • Tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions can be seen at the margins of the intertriginous patch.
  2. Candidal paronychia: Swelling of nail fold
  3. Candidal balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.
  4. Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

Treatment:

 

  • Topical: Antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.
  • Oral: Fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia

  • This refers to an infection of the nail fold, leading to a painful and red swelling around the nail.
  • It can be due to bacterial or candidal infection.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer

  • This is an open sore or wound commonly located on the bottom of the foot in people with diabetes.
  • Factors leading to diabetic foot ulcers include neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, foot deformities, and trauma.
  • The skin around the ulcer may be calloused or discolored but not typically macerated.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

  • This is a serious skin disorder caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It primarily affects infants and young children.
  • It is characterized by blistering and the appearance that the top layer of skin is scalded or burned.
  • SSSS affects larger areas of the body and often starts with facial erythema, widespread redness, and blisters, which then rupture, leaving raw areas. Maceration of toe web spaces would not be a primary symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candidal intertrigo can be identified by the classic presentation of erythema, maceration, and possible white exudate in skin folds, such as the web spaces between fingers, distinguishing it from conditions that affect the nail folds, feet, or involve widespread skin desquamation.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page nos 32.61-32.63

questions.text: Corticospinal tract crosses the midline at: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lower medulla

 

The corticospinal tract is a major pathway that carries motor signals from the brain down to the spinal cord to control voluntary movements, particularly those involving the limbs. This tract originates in the cerebral cortex, descends through the brainstem, and continues into the spinal cord.

 

At the level of the lower medulla, the corticospinal tract fibers cross to the opposite side of the body in a process known as the pyramidal decussation. This crossing of the fibers is crucial as it means that each side of the brain controls the opposite side of the body. The pyramidal decussation marks the transition from the medulla oblongata to the spinal cord and is a key anatomical landmark in the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is a part of the brainstem situated above the medulla. While the corticospinal tract passes through the pons, it does not cross the midline here. The crossing, or decussation, occurs only in the lower medulla.

 

Option C. Middle medulla: While the corticospinal tract descends through the middle medulla, the actual crossing of the fibers (decussation) occurs further down in the lower medulla, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Midbrain: The corticospinal tract passes through the midbrain as it descends from the cortex, but no crossing occurs at this level. The pyramidal decussation occurs lower, at the level of the medulla.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corticospinal tract crosses the midline at the lower medulla in a process known as pyramidal decussation, which is essential for the control of voluntary movements by the opposite side of the brain.

choices.text: Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria
Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis
Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Behçet's disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

 

Behçet's disease is a chronic, multisystem vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, skin lesions, and more. Genital ulcers in Behçet's typically occur on the scrotum in males and the vulva in females. The dorsum of the penis is rarely involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria: Correct. The International Study Group (ISG) includes the pathergy test (a sterile pustule at the site of needle prick) as a supportive criterion.

 

Option C. Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease: Correct. The oral ulcers of Behçet’s resemble aphthous ulcers and can be clinically indistinguishable from those seen in Crohn’s disease.

 

Option D. Bilateral pan uveitis: Correct. Ocular involvement is common and may present as anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, or pan uveitis—often bilateral and sight-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behçet’s disease typically affects the scrotum, vulva, eyes, and oral mucosa. Ulcers on the dorsum of the penis are atypical, making option B the incorrect statement.

questions.text: Among the given options, which layer of the scalp is vascular ? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Superficial fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The superficial fascia of the scalp is the highly vascular layer containing numerous blood vessels. This layer is more fibrous and dense in the center than at the periphery of the head. It contains many blood vessels and provides the proper medium for passage of vessels and nerves to the skin. The rich vascularity in this layer explains why scalp wounds bleed profusely, yet heal rapidly. The vessels in this layer are held open by the fibrous tissue when cut, making hemostasis more difficult.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Pericranium - This is the fifth or deepest layer of the scalp, which is the periosteum covering the skull bones. It's loosely attached to the surface of the bones except at the sutures where it's firmly adherent.

 

Option c) Skin - This is the outermost layer of the scalp that contains hair follicles, sweat glands and sebaceous glands, but is not the primary vascular layer.

 

Option d) Aponeurosis - This is the third layer of the scalp, also called galea aponeurotica or epicranial aponeurosis. It's a tough fibrous sheet connecting the frontalis and occipitalis muscles but is not particularly vascular.

 

Education Objective:

 

The superficial fascia of the scalp is the highly vascular layer containing numerous blood vessels that makes scalp injuries bleed profusely as these vessels are prevented from retracting due to the dense fibrous tissue surrounding them.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect finding in Mirizzi syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hemobilia

 

Explanation:

 

Mirizzi syndrome occurs when a gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, causing inflammation and extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct. This mechanical obstruction leads to obstructive jaundice. Hemobilia (bleeding into the biliary tract) is not a feature of Mirizzi syndrome but rather a distinct pathology typically seen after liver trauma, vascular malformations, or biliary procedures, where erosion of a blood vessel leads to bleeding into the biliary tree.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jaundice - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. Patients present with obstructive jaundice due to the mechanical compression of the common hepatic duct, resulting in the classic triad of jaundice, pruritis, and clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Cystic duct obstruction - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. The pathophysiology begins with a stone becoming impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing obstruction and surrounding inflammation that then affects nearby structures.

 

Option C. Cholecystocholedochal fistula - This is a correct feature seen in progressive Mirizzi syndrome. The Csendes classification describes how the impacted stone can erode through the wall of the cystic duct into the common hepatic duct, creating a fistula that may involve varying degrees of the duct circumference (Types 2-4).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirizzi syndrome involves obstructive jaundice caused by extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct by gallstones impacted in the cystic duct, potentially leading to fistula formation, but does not involve bleeding into the biliary tree (hemobilia).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pompholyx is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most common site is soles

 

  • Pompholyx (also known as dyshidrotic eczema or vesicular eczema) is characterized by intensely pruritic and painful deep-seated vesicles that have a sago grain-like appearance. 
  • These vesicles typically occur at the sides of digits rather than primarily on the soles. 
  • The most common sites are the fingers and palms, with soles being affected sometimes but not as the primary or most common location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sago-grain like vesicles - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx lesions have a characteristic "sago grain-like appearance" which refers to their deep-seated vesicular presentation.

 

 

 

Option C. Pruritus may precede eruption - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx is described as "intensely pruritic" and itching is a hallmark symptom that can occur before visible lesions appear.

 

Option D. Symmetric distribution - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx typically presents with symmetric distribution, affecting both hands or both feet in a similar pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pompholyx is characterized by intensely pruritic deep-seated vesicles with sago grain-like appearance occurring primarily on fingers and palms, less commonly on soles, and typically presents with symmetric distribution.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: A patient with unilateral, unilocular suppurating bubo and a single sinus tract is observed to have a primary genital ulcer. The likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

  • Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers accompanied by unilateral suppurative (pus-filled) inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo). 

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen in chancroid.
  • The key connection here is the presence of both a primary genital ulcer and suppurating bubo with sinus tract formation. 
  • Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and has an incubation period of 3-5 days. 
  • The genital ulcer in chancroid is soft, tender, with necrotic base and ragged undermined edges that bleeds on touch. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum):

 

  • Incorrect because in LGV, the primary genital ulcer is transient and often goes unnoticed or has already healed by the time the bubo develops. 
  • The question explicitly mentions the presence of both the ulcer and bubo simultaneously, which is characteristic of chancroid rather than LGV.
  • LGV buboes also tend to exhibit the "groove sign" due to involvement of both inguinal and femoral nodes.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Genitalis:

 

  • Incorrect because while herpes causes painful genital ulcers (typically multiple grouped vesicles that rupture to form ulcers with polycyclic margins), it does not cause suppurative bubo formation with sinus tracts. 
  • Herpes may cause bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, but not the formation of buboes that suppurate.

 

Option D. Primary Syphilis:

 

  • Incorrect because primary syphilis causes a painless, indurated, clean-based ulcer (chancre) with non-suppurative bilateral lymphadenopathy. 
  • The lymph nodes in primary syphilis are typically described as "shotty" and do not form suppurative buboes or sinus tracts. 
  • The lymphadenopathy is also usually bilateral rather than unilateral.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The combination of a primary genital ulcer with a concurrent unilateral suppurating bubo that forms a sinus tract is highly characteristic of chancroid, distinguishing it from other sexually transmitted infections like LGV (where the primary lesion is often absent by the time buboes appear), herpes (which doesn't cause suppurative buboes), and syphilis (which causes painless, non-suppurating lymphadenopathy).

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about dementia and differentiate it from delirium, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Clouding of consciousness

 

Explanation: 

 

Clouding of consciousness is a characteristic feature of delirium, not dementia. The disturbance of consciousness is considered one of the hallmark symptoms of delirium and represents a key distinguishing feature between these two neurocognitive disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect): Dementia typically has an insidious onset with gradual progression, while delirium has a sudden onset. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect): Most dementias are irreversible and progressive conditions, unlike delirium which is usually reversible if the underlying cause is identified and treated. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect): In dementia, memory impairment follows a pattern where recent memory is affected first, followed by immediate memory, and finally remote memory in later stages. In delirium, immediate and recent memory are primarily affected while remote memory remains relatively intact. Impaired remote memory in later stages is a feature of dementia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key differences between dementia and delirium include: dementia has insidious onset and progressive course while delirium has sudden onset and fluctuating course; consciousness is preserved in dementia but disturbed in delirium; and dementia is often irreversible whereas delirium is usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

 

The Declaration of Oslo was adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA) to address the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion. Therapeutic abortion refers to the termination of pregnancy performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, preserve her physical or mental health, or in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo is the relevant document that deals with the ethical guidelines for doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment.

 

Option C. Hunger: The Declaration of Malta on Hunger Strikes provides ethical guidelines for physicians concerning the treatment of hunger strikers. This declaration emphasizes the importance of respecting the autonomy of individuals who engage in hunger strikes.

 

Option D. Ethical aspects of medical research: The Declaration of Helsinki is the key document that outlines ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the necessity of informed consent, the welfare of research participants, and the importance of conducting research with scientific integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: Meckel’s diverticulum is a derivative of which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Vitellointestinal duct

 

Explanation: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct (also called vitelline duct, yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct). During embryonic development, the midgut communicates with the yolk sac through the vitellointestinal duct. Normally, this duct obliterates completely by the 7th week of development, but when the proximal part persists, it forms Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Allantoic diverticulum: This is a ventral projection of hindgut into the connecting stalk. Its proximal part gets incorporated into the apex of urinary bladder and its distal part undergoes fibrosis to form urachus. It has no relation to Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option C. Ventral mesogastrium: This is the embryological structure from which the lesser omentum and falciform ligament develop. It has no association with Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option D. Ductus arteriosus: This is a vascular structure derived from the 6th aortic arch that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal life. After birth, it obliterates to form the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum follows the "rule of 2s" - it affects 2% of population, is about 2 inches long, occurs 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, is twice as common in males, and only 2% of patients are symptomatic.

questions.text: Which nerve is prone to injury during venesection in a burns patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saphenous nerve

 

Venesection, or phlebotomy, is a procedure where a vein is punctured to withdraw blood or administer fluids. In burns patients, venesection may be more challenging due to damaged skin and underlying tissues. The great saphenous vein is a common site for venesection, especially in the lower limb.

 

The saphenous nerve runs alongside the great saphenous vein in the leg. This close anatomical relationship makes the saphenous nerve particularly vulnerable to injury during venesection in this area. Damage to the saphenous nerve can result in sensory deficits along the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is located in the thigh and supplies motor and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and part of the leg. It is not typically associated with the great saphenous vein and therefore is less likely to be injured during venesection.

 

Option B. Peroneal nerve: The peroneal (or fibular) nerve runs along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and is not in close proximity to the great saphenous vein. It is thus not at significant risk during venesection in the lower limb.

 

Option C. Sural nerve: The sural nerve provides sensory innervation to the posterior and lateral aspects of the leg and foot. It runs alongside the small saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein, so it is less likely to be injured during venesection involving the great saphenous vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, which runs alongside the great saphenous vein, is particularly prone to injury during venesection in a burns patient, especially when accessing the great saphenous vein in the lower limb.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia was on olanzapine therapy for a few months. It was effective in controlling the symptoms, but the patient stopped taking this drug. What can be the most likely reason? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight gain

 

Explanation:

 

  • Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it is effective in controlling both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, it is associated with several adverse effects. 
  • The most common reason patients discontinue olanzapine therapy is weight gain. 
  • Olanzapine, along with clozapine, has the highest risk of causing metabolic side effects collectively known as lipodystrophy syndrome. This syndrome includes hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and significant weight gain. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia: This is incorrect. Because tardive dyskinesia is more commonly associated with typical (first-generation) antipsychotic drugs like haloperidol rather than atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine. Atypical antipsychotics have a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms including tardive dyskinesia.

 

Option C. Agranulocytosis: This is incorrect. Because agranulocytosis is a characteristic adverse effect of clozapine, not olanzapine. Clozapine requires regular monitoring of white blood cell counts due to this potentially fatal side effect.

 

Option D. Muscular dystonia: This is incorrect. Because muscular dystonia is an extrapyramidal symptom more commonly associated with typical antipsychotic drugs. Atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a much lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of Atypical anti- Psychotics:

 

Side effects

 

  • Cause lipodystrophy syndrome characterized by
    • ↑Glucose
    • ↑Lipids
    • Weight gain
    • Insulin Resistance
  • Risk is highest with clozapine and olanzapine

questions.text: Most common cancer in India in females is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer among females. It has surpassed cervical cancer, which previously held the top position. Breast cancer has a high incidence due to various factors, including genetic predisposition, lifestyle changes, and increased awareness leading to higher detection rates. Early detection through screening programs, such as mammography, plays a crucial role in managing and reducing the mortality associated with breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervix: Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India. It is caused primarily by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. Despite its high incidence, it is not as common as breast cancer.

 

Option C. Ovary: Ovarian cancer is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers. It often presents at a later stage due to nonspecific symptoms, making it a significant cause of gynecologic cancer mortality.

 

Option D. Endometrium: Endometrial cancer is also less common than breast and cervical cancers in India. It typically occurs in postmenopausal women and is often associated with hormonal imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among females in India, highlighting the importance of regular screening and early detection to improve outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical local anesthetic used in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proparacaine 0.5%

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is a topical anesthetic commonly used in cataract surgery. It is favored because it is highly effective when applied in the form of eye drops, providing sufficient anesthesia for superficial surgeries like cataract extraction. Proparacaine has a rapid onset of action, typically anesthetizing the eye within five minutes of application. This quick onset is particularly advantageous for surgeries that are short in duration, such as cataract surgery, which generally lasts between 15 to 30 minutes.

 

Moreover, Proparacaine has minimal systemic absorption, which means it has a lower risk of systemic side effects, making it a safe choice for a wide range of patients. These characteristics make Proparacaine the ideal anesthetic for cataract surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine 0.5%: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic but is typically used for longer procedures or in different forms, such as injections for regional anesthesia. It is not commonly used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries due to its longer duration of action and potential for systemic toxicity.

 

Option C. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic, not used as a topical local anesthetic. It is employed for general anesthesia in different surgical contexts, but it is not relevant for cataract surgery.

 

Option D. N₂O (Nitrous Oxide): Nitrous Oxide is also an inhalational anesthetic, primarily used for its analgesic and anesthetic properties in various procedures, but it is not used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is the preferred topical anesthetic for cataract surgery due to its rapid onset, appropriate duration of action, and minimal systemic absorption.

questions.text: The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves the mixing of common household chemicals to produce: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. H₂S and other poisonous gases

 

Explanation:

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves mixing common household chemicals (typically an acid like toilet bowl cleaner with sulfur-containing products) to produce hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) and other toxic gases. H₂S is a highly toxic gas that inhibits cellular respiration by binding to cytochrome oxidase. This method became notorious in Japan where individuals would mix these chemicals in enclosed spaces like cars or small rooms, leading to rapid death by toxic gas inhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deadly foam - The technique does not primarily produce a deadly foam. While some foaming may occur during the chemical reaction, the lethal component is the gaseous hydrogen sulfide released.

 

Option C. Deadly acidic compound - Though acids may be used in the reaction, the deadly element is not the acidic compound itself but rather the gaseous products (primarily H₂S) released from the chemical reaction.

 

Option D. Deadly fluid cyanide compound - The technique does not produce cyanide compounds. Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is chemically distinct from cyanide compounds, though both act as cellular asphyxiants by different mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' produces hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) gas, which acts as a cellular poison by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to rapid asphyxiation and death.

questions.text: Which of the following locations contains the GLUT-1 glucose transporter? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Placenta

 

Explanation:


GLUT-1 is a glucose transporter protein that facilitates the transport of glucose across cell membranes via facilitated diffusion. This transporter is constitutively expressed and functions independently of insulin. GLUT-1 is highly expressed in the placenta where it plays a critical role in transferring glucose from maternal to fetal circulation, ensuring the developing fetus receives adequate glucose supply throughout pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Skeletal muscle: Skeletal muscle primarily expresses GLUT-4, not GLUT-1. GLUT-4 is an insulin-responsive glucose transporter that translocates from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane in response to insulin.
  • Option b. Adipose tissue: Similar to skeletal muscle, adipose tissue predominantly expresses GLUT-4, which mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in fat cells.
  • Option c. Jejunum: The jejunum primarily utilizes SGLT (sodium-glucose linked transporter) for glucose absorption across the brush border membrane and GLUT-2 for basolateral transport, not GLUT-1.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

GLUT-1 is a constitutively active glucose transporter that facilitates the passive transport of glucose across plasma membranes in tissues requiring constant glucose supply regardless of insulin levels, with particularly high expression in the placenta, erythrocytes, and blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histidine

 

Histidine contains an imidazole ring in its side chain, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~6.8-7.0).

 

The imidazole ring allows histidine to reversibly bind and release protons, making it an excellent buffer.

 

This buffering action is important in maintaining blood pH and plays a key role in hemoglobin function (part of the histidine residue in hemoglobin helps buffer blood pH changes).

 

"Histidine has an imidazole ring, which allows it to accept and donate protons at physiological pH."

 

"Histidine is the most effective buffer at physiological pH due to its imidazole ring."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Incorrect

 

  • Has a guanidinium group with pKa ~12.5, making it a strong base, but not an effective buffer at physiological pH (~7.4).
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide (NO), emphasizing its role in vasodilation rather than acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Incorrect

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid and is used in the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin.
  • Tryptophan contains an indole ring, making it non-polar and hydrophobic.
  • Since buffering depends on the ability to accept and donate protons near physiological pH (~7.4), tryptophan is not effective as a buffer.

 

Option D. Tyrosine: Incorrect

 

  • Tyrosine's is derived from phenylalanine and has a role in thyroid hormone synthesis, catecholamine production (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine), and melanin production.
  • Tyrosine has a phenol (-OH) group, with a pKa of ~10.1, meaning it does not donate or accept protons effectively at physiological pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histidine is the best amino acid buffer in blood because of its imidazole ring, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~7).

 

The imidazole group allows histidine to act as a proton donor or acceptor, making it an ideal buffer.

questions.text: Following delivery of a preterm baby, the baby died in the NICU despite all efforts. What medication would be given to the mother for reducing breast tenderness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cabergoline

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist and is the drug of choice for suppressing lactation. It works by inhibiting prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland, which reduces milk production and alleviates breast engorgement and tenderness.

 

Cabergoline is preferred because it is effective, has a favorable side effect profile, and is well-tolerated by most patients. It is also used in conditions like galactorrhea where suppression of lactation is desired.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: While dopamine agonists like cabergoline work to suppress prolactin, dopamine itself is not used directly for this purpose in clinical settings. Cabergoline, being a dopamine agonist, is more specifically tailored for this function.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Ergot alkaloids have some dopamine agonist activity and can suppress prolactin, but they are not the drug of choice for lactation suppression due to their side effects and less favorable risk profile compared to cabergoline.

 

Option D. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog used to prevent gastric ulcers, induce labor, and manage postpartum hemorrhage, but it has no role in lactation suppression or reducing breast tenderness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline is the preferred medication for suppressing lactation and reducing breast tenderness in cases where breastfeeding is not desired or possible, such as after neonatal death

choices.text: Erect and real image is formed
Need to keep condenser close to patient’s eye

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Indirect Ophthalmoscopy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-5x magnification is provided

 

Explanation:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy is a technique used to examine the fundus of the eye from a distance, typically at arm's length. It provides a stereoscopic (three-dimensional) view of the retina with a wide field of view, allowing visualization up to the ora serrata (peripheral retina). One of its key characteristics is the lower magnification compared to direct ophthalmoscopy.

 

Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 3-5x magnification of the fundus. This lower magnification is a trade-off for the wider field of view that it offers. The 20 diopter lens is most commonly used for indirect ophthalmoscopy, and the examination is typically performed with the patient in a lying position.

 

The indirect ophthalmoscope consists of a head-mounted light source and a handheld condensing lens (usually 20D). This setup creates an inverted and reverted real image between the observer and the condensing lens, providing binocular vision and excellent stereopsis, which helps in detecting elevations and depressions in the retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erect and real image is formed: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, an inverted and real image is formed. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, which produces an erect and virtual image. The inverted nature of the image in indirect ophthalmoscopy requires the examiner to mentally reorient the image for proper interpretation.

 

Option B. Need to keep condenser close to patient's eye: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, the examiner stays at a distance (around arm's length) from the patient, and the condensing lens is held approximately 1-2 inches in front of the patient's eye. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, where the examiner needs to be close to the patient's eye (approximately 2-3 cm).

 

Option C. 15x magnification is provided: Incorrect. Direct ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 15x magnification, not indirect ophthalmoscopy. The higher magnification in direct ophthalmoscopy allows for detailed examination of small structures but limits the field of view compared to indirect ophthalmoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides a wide field of view with lower magnification (3-5x) compared to direct ophthalmoscopy, forming an inverted and real image that allows examination of the peripheral retina up to the ora serrata with good stereopsis.

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet
Tubing near mouth and nose
Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

 

Free-flow oxygen refers to the administration of oxygen without the need for positive pressure ventilation. It is typically used to provide supplemental oxygen to neonates who are breathing spontaneously.

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow freely into the mask and can provide free-flow oxygen.
  • Face mask: Using a face mask can administer free-flow oxygen effectively.
  • Tubing near mouth and nose: Placing oxygen tubing near the mouth and nose is a common method to deliver free-flow oxygen.

 

However, bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet does not provide a means for oxygen to flow freely. This method relies on positive pressure ventilation, where the bag is squeezed to push air (and oxygen if connected) into the neonate's lungs, not allowing for the passive flow of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow through the inlet, providing free-flow oxygen.

 

Option B. Face mask: A face mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen effectively.

 

Option C. Tubing near mouth and nose: This is a standard method for administering free-flow oxygen to neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: Heavy metal chelators are all EXCEPT:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxime

 

Oximes are not typically used as heavy metal chelators. Oximes are compounds containing the functional group R1C=NOH. They are more commonly associated with the reactivation of acetylcholinesterase in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease and lead poisoning.

 

Option C. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): BAL is a heavy metal chelator used for arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning.

 

Option D. Trientine: Trientine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heavy metal chelators play a crucial role in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. They work by binding to toxic heavy metals and aiding in their elimination from the body. Each heavy metal chelator may have specific indications and is used for particular heavy metal poisonings.
